reviewText:
I decided to buy the game after seeing the first two episodes of Jesse Cox & Dodger's playthrough of it, and it's an interesting game if perhaps leaving a lot of decision making out of the equation at times (such as non-interactive cutscenes that could have been timed puzzles/QTEs) and you can't accuse/arrest the wrong person, which I add only for completion as that may or may not be important to you as a player.

I appreciate the HD video, but at times not the acting which can range from being (unintentionally?) comical (especially the player character Inspector Jenks, who also perhaps got his dress sense cues from McCloud rather than Morse, which I find to be diverting) and then the acting being ineffectua throughl to playing the scenes straight. The story is okay, but could have been solved almost immediately with the all-important clue being blatantly obvious and yet the option to compare and contrast the statements given yielded no results.  Not until the final in-game hour anyway.

Then there are the elements of a paranormal/horror plot, which sadly was only touched upon and could have made this much more of a game. More than likely the budget constraints put paid to developing that plot, but at least there were little touches in the form of short scenes informing the player of potential events (one I recall being optional, that being the scene in the Reading Room where you're told to go away because we're about to start a session").

As it stands

Games like Gabriel Knight, Phantasmagoria and the Tex Murphy titles started to embrace Full Motion Video footage.
Initially it was viewed as a novelty, real actors playing out the narrative in all the interlaced video glory the 90's could muster.
FMV seemed liked a perfect fit for cut scenes and narrative heavy titles and I loved it!

reviewText:
Oh was this an experience to play. It was incredible and I was hooked from the start. Not many games can have me playing for 3 hours running and have me feeling like i've only been playing for about half an hour.

I feel like there isn't a whole lot I can say about this game without spoiling the story to readers so i'm going to structure this review into a few smaller sections explaining the main premise of the game and linking in my opinions/experience.

Gameplay
Contradiction is an FMV style game. I'll admit though I have never before played an FMV game. I wasn't around during the FMV craze that I heard about. So I am not sure what typical gameplay is like in them type of games. But I can explain how gameplay functions in Contradiction.

You play as a detective. You are investigating the death of a character named Kate Vine. You do this by exploring the small village and finding the clues along the way. All areas that you explore are real areas and nothing is animated. The clues that you find can be used to interogate other characters that you meet accross the way. After asking all the questions to people your goal is to spot who is lieing. You have to put two responses together that disagree with each other and then interogate the person more about this Contradiction.

The game is an investigatory experience. It could be compared to the likes of L.A NOIRE or Sherlock Holmes. But Contradiction decides to strip it's core mechanics down to the basics. They decide to focus on the questioning mechanic. The responses are well thought out and it is very enjoyable to listen to what the characters have to say. You often find yourself linking replies that you got right at the start of the game to ones that were said very late in the game. This means you need to have a good memory or else you could find yourself having to look through pages of replies. Although boy is it satisfying when you finally find a contradiction amongst all of the replies.

The UI
Now this game is controlled entirely with the keyboard. The UI is key to making sure the experience is fun. It does this well to an extent. The initial controls the game gives you are horrible. You probably want to rebind them to more appropriate keys as soon as you start playing. Although even navigating the controls screen isn't great. There is no way that I could see to just rebind one single key. You have to go through the entire list and rebind each key instead of just picking one. What I would like to see is the introduction of mouse control, even if it was just across the main menu. It would definitely make the experience a bit better.

Then you have the map. Initially it is kinda confusing to use. You have 2 choices of how to explore. You can use the map and go to a location straight away using that. But you can only use the keyboard to control it again. Originally I didn't realize you could use the map for movement because I was trying to use the mouse to click on the location. But once you realize that you can then it is a much better form of movement. The second way of navigation is through the arrow keys. You get given a choice of places to go to next from your current location. The problem with this is that the game seems to confusingly decide to change orientation. This means you can't just spam up for example to keep going in that direction. You need to keep an eye on what direction orientation the world has randomly decided to go to. This factor confused me for quite a while and made me go in the wrong direction numerous times. But I did get used to it in the end.

The Characters
So each character is played by a real life person including the person you play as. The character development throughout the game is great. Your really do get to know the characters which is key in an investigatory game where your main focus is to spot the criminal. Some of the acting is vastly exagorated, especially Jenks(Your own character). But this is OK I think because it makes sure you don't miss anything but sometimes it is a little bit cringeworthy.

Some characters in contradiction I felt were amazing actors and definitely gave their characters a personalilty. To name a few the characters of Ryan, James and Simon were played excelently and I want to take the time to praise their actors. Obviously the rest of the other actors were also great as well. But there were some moments were I felt the acting was kinda bad. I have to wonder if it was the bad dialog that the script writers had given them that made these moments cringeworthy. But the majority of the dialog and acting was amazing and I definitely enjoyed it.

Summary
So would I recommend Contradiction. YES, YES, Oh boy yes. It was an incredible experience the likes of which I personally havn't seen before. If you love detective games this is definitely the game for you. It sees the detective experience from a different perspective that isn't usually focused on in games. The game ends gearing up for a sequel. But they need peoples support on this game if they are to make another game. I really hope this game succeeds because I would love to play another game of this and experience some more backstory behind the characters. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone. Especially at the very reasonable price point of £6.99. It is a bargain for how much fun you get out of it. It took me 8 hours to complete which is well worth the price.

A good game that should definitely be considered.

I can't honestly describe how much I love and adore this game. Everything about it is incredibly charming and loveable with a hint of camp and hilarity. Its on the verge of selfawareness, knowing that it is goofy, but there are enough characters that are believeable that it works. In no way I'm saying that the game is bad, its that the quality and tone rides a very thin line and frankly balances perfectly.

I highly recommend this game, whether to just support the developer so that similar efforts can me made, or if you are looking for a murder mystery with a lot of camp and charm nailed in around the framework.

Suggestion to the developer for a sequel, retain as much of the cast as possible, just create a new mystery for Jenks to solve with eerily similar characters.

reviewText:
Contradiction is a live-action FMV Murder-Mystery game. You play as Inspector Jenks, a British Policeman who goes to investigate the death of a girl named Katie in a small outskirt village. Her death was investigated and called a suicide, but there was morphine in her blood at her time of death and her driver's license was pinned to a tree in the forest away from the scene of her death, leading our character to suspect there's more involved in this case which he takes personal interest in. His work quickly leads him to find there is indeed something going on in this town...

So, like many FMV games, this game does have an edge of B-charm, laugh-out-loud moments, a lot of this comes from some of the acting and facial expressions the actors can have in specific scenes. But that's not to say this is a so-bad-it's-good type of game, in fact the opposite, it actually got kind of gripping as it developed and in contrast some moments were acted out rather well. It's got a multi-layered mystery that gets deeper and deeper as the night goes on, and is actually surprisingly interesting.

Gameplay is rather basic. You walk around a town and look for clues hidden about, and people to interview. When you interview people, you take out clues, both physical and conversation topics you earn from talking to others, and watch FMV scenes as they interact. When the scene is done, your character has taken 'notes' to the key points of the discussion. You then can take the key notes from that discussion, and every other discussion you've had with that character, and try and spot any 'contradictions' the character may have said. If you find a contradicting point, it triggers another scene, which either will lead to you having to do further digging or creates a new conversation topic you can raise up to others. Other conversation topics can be found around as objects or weird things in town that strike up a good conversation topic, and some rare objects found can be used to explore deeper certain areas in the village.

The game has a solid cast of something like 10 main characters, and is backed by some rather good-quality video for the backgrounds, FMV scenes, etc., and an actually pretty wonderful soundtrack. Music added a lot to specific scenes, and there were a few moments without music where you can hear the atmosphere sounds and drone noises that made some scenes legitimately creepy. On that, while the game is down-toned most of the time, there's the odd scene that plays every once in a while that can catch you off-guard, something that's just kind of creepy, or unexpected, shocking in some cases. I won't spoil anything with that, but the game has a few sudden scenes that happen as you investigate that might catch you off-guard.

It's got a few minor flaws. There are a few times where something the character said was obviously a lie or a contradiction to something you already knew, but because you didn't have the 'conversation topic' piece, you couldn't accuse them of this. A few contradictions (or what seem like contradictions) the game doesn't think quite are. Also the game, while it does have an ending and wraps up the case, proposes more questions, especially near the very end, and has several loose plot threads. They seem to be a sequel hook, and past the game credits a message pops-up confirms this saying  Thanks For Playing!"

reviewText:
If you like Full Motion Videogame's from the '90's then this is certainly a game that you should buy. That is why I jumped right on it when I found it.

You take on the role of an Inspector. There has been a recent mysterious death of a young girl. Your job is to question the residents of the small town and try to figure out what has happened. Picking up objects to solve puzzles or unlock new topics to talk to the residents about. This at times can get a bit repetitive (conversation-find object-contradict-repeat). But it doesn't bother me, because the storyline and character are very interesting and suck me right into the game.

The actor's deliver a solid acting performance and are enjoyable to watch, making the FMV fun and more realistic to play/watch.

+ Price (I would easily pay double or even triple for this game)
+ A really well done FMV
+ Interesting story
+ Puzzles are hard but not too hard
+ Great acting and type casting
+ Can be at times funny and humoristic
+ Play a detective
+ Great music
+ Lovely accents

- I couldn't figure out how to get it full screen

I would like to express how happy I am with FMV's popping up more and more on Steam and I hope and look forward to play the sequel of Contradiction - Spot the Liar! Seriously get this game!

\m/

Bought this after watching the hilarious Giantbomb videos, and man this game is awesome. The UI is terrible, but get past that and get used to the weird controls and dive deep into the world of Detective Jenks and his amazing hat, as he proffers the devil horns to all and sundry in his search for justice.

The game involves interrogating  several people about a mysterious death in a small English village. You must sift through their dialogue and point out contradictions. There's also some extremely light puzzle solving involved.

Everything from the title of the game to the interface screams that this isn't going to be good, but it has so much heart and love put into it, the acting is great, if (appropriately) hammy in places and the music is wonderful.

reviewText: There is a certain level of charm exclusive to FMV games. I hated them back then, but now they're all endearing in their own special way. With the computer graphics of today, we can achieve practically anything. That really isn't as exciting as it used to be. Maybe I'm just getting old. I'd probably start yelling at clouds, but I never go outside. Whatever the case, Contradiction - Spot the Liar! is a great example of what the medium is capable of.\n\nDetective Inspector Jenks is tasked with solving the mysterious death of a young woman. Over the course of a single night, he will collect evidence, interview suspects, and discover contradictions. In terms of game-design, the process isn't complicated in any way. Take the Phoenix Wright series for example. In those games, your primary method of progression is tied to spotting contradictions. If you mess up, you're punished with a loss of life". There are no punishments for mistakes in this game. You can even take as much time as you need to solve the mystery. I appreciate the more casual approach to this investigation. Games with FMV (Full Motion Video) are very rare nowadays and had their peak during the 90s when 3D graphics weren't as elaborate as they are today. But they have a certain charm to them, just like watching an 'interactive movie' as such games are often described. You don't get that alot of that feeling with the artifical rendered characters and scenery anymore. With that said, being an adventure-enthusiast, it's quite a treat to see 'Contradiction' has found it's way onto the steam store.

What is the game about? You play as a scotland yard officer investigating a supposed suicide in a small village in england. Many facts of the initial investigation didn't quite fit into the whole picture, that's the reason the player has until 12pm to find any evidence that proves that the victim did not kill itself, but that other circumstances where the cause of death. The game progresses one hour at a time, effectively dividing the game into several chapters".

reviewText:
The CD-ROM era both birthed and killed the Full Motion Video game. While still in its crib, a generation-long curse was laid upon the genre, dooming all creations branded with the FMV tag to receive nothing but scorn and contempt in every village around the world. And to be honest, the reputation was wholly deserved.

Decades later, hard drive space is now cheap and the codecs plentiful. The creators also seem wiser this time around, focusing on small and intimate, non-branching storylines and cutting the flashy sizzle reel tricks and animations altogether.

Contradiction is, like other recent FMV games such as Her Story and Tesla Effect, a detective mystery: A girl has been found dead in a small rural British town. You play as Inspector Jenks who's been sent to investigate, mostly interviewing the residents about the incident and doing some minor inventory-based sleuthing.

Chats with people open up more points of discussion, and the idea is to find contradictions in the statements of the suspects. This is easier said than done, since the conversations always bring up dozens of possible subjects and pinpointing the slips of the tongue requires attention and thought. Just randomly trying things will get you nowhere.

I was surprised at how engrossed in the game I got. The characters are intriguing and I have no major problems with the acting (Jenks himself can get a bit over the top on occasion, though). The setting and the plot are also atmospheric, with a lot of hints towards something truly sinister. The music properly sets the mood, and the village itself is visually a rather charmingly beautiful little slice of English countryside.

Pacing around the town can get slightly frustrating if you get stuck, but the game has its own elegantly integrated hint system so you're never truly lost. The game is definitely no walk in the park either, so expect your little grey cells to get an outing they probably deserve in this day and age.

The only downside of Contradiction is that you can sometimes see a few corners cut where budget limitations apparently came into play, however, cheapo after effects are blessedly kept to a minimum. Biggest bummer is that some of the major story strands are never brought into conclusion after the case is cracked, but are left to be resolved in a potential sequel.

Anyhow, this is FMV gaming done right. I finished the game in one nine-hour sitting and had fun the whole time. That's more than I can say for most games, FMV or not.

reviewText:
Contradiction: Spot the Liar is a love letter to Agatha Christie and other murder mysteries of its genre. Everything is saturated with style and charm, including the main character. Your job is to guide our detective as he interviews and gathers clues in this seemingly dickensian like village. Of course not everything is at it appears and it up to you to unravel the mystery. Being a FMV(Full-Motion Video) game, Contradiction is completely based off its acting. Which it does exquisitely. The mechanics of the game while very simple, are complimented by the clever writing and eerie atmosphere. As hours go by in the game, more of the story is slowly revealed to you and the plot thickens. The contradiction system in the game has you matching statements and clues, trying to catch suspects in a lie. This isn't easy in the least but there are helpful hint systems in place if you do get stuck. While many will compare this with Her Story, this is a completely different experience. You are far more involved and progress is completely based on your keen senses of listening and deduction. There are times that Contradiction can feel a little cheesy but that all plays into the genre of the game. So get your thinking cap on, its time to solve some delicious murder!!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/YLxD7ZGppJM
I hope you enjoy!

reviewText: I just stumbled upon the game’s store page a few days ago and it piqued my interest. Apparently it was a Kickstarter game that somehow passed by my radar and it’s headed by Tim Follin, the composer for games like Plok and New Zealand Story. It’s actually been out on iOS for a couple of months as well but I didn’t know that either. After having completed Her Story when it came out and loving it I was up for another FMV detective game and Contradiction didn’t disappoint.\n\nUnlike Her Story which took its own unique approach, Contradiction is very much like a traditional 90’s FMV adventure game only upgraded to the HD age. The primary gameplay is finding evidence and then using that evidence to find contradictions between a person’s statements, it’s a bit like Phoenix Wright in execution. The game is never truly obtuse either, I beat the game with no hints. It’s clear that it was meant for mobile first because you only use the keyboard and not the mouse, and it’s a bit clunky at first, but you get used to it fairly quick. The game is pretty low budget and it shows in that there’s not many varied locations and the like but they also worked really well within in these constraints because its real quality, the FMV is very clear, its shot well, and the game is really atmospheric. The acting is quite solid and the protagonist, Inspector Jenks, is a ham but in a likable way. The mystery is entertaining too, though it’s not really complex and there’s never any real “Holy sh*t” moments or the like, but it will definitely keep you engaged.  Overall Contradiction is a very solid game and if you’re in the market for some new school FMV adventure games Contradiction is definitely worth your time.

reviewText:
Contradiction is not perfect by any means but still a decent game and worth the price. Everything is HD and the audio quality is good, but they do just slap a colour filter on some scenes to make it seem later in the day. A small detail but I found it a bit odd.

The acting varies from great to being a bit campy. Overall I didn't mind but the main character, Inspector Jenks, did come across as too 'happy' or 'nice' when he is supposed to be investigating suspects in a murder case. Paul Darrow as Paul Rand was superb though.

My two biggest complaints are that you can't actually get the wrong person and the inventory is a bit of a mess.

You progress through the investigation 'one hour' at a time and are supposed to solve it before midnight. But time only passes when you reach a certain point in the story and confront a character with contradictions in their statements. Until then time doesn't pass in-game, so the time limit is a bit arbitrary. You also can't fail, something which would have been interesting but is not explored at all and would have added some replay value.

The 'inventory' is cluttered, including items (screwdriver, torch etc.) as well as evidence to present to suspects and statements to ask them about. But when you are interrogating someone you are given a list with all of them in, even things you can't actually speak to them about and items that you only use once in the story. They are colour coded but I think that splitting them up would make a lot more sense and make the questioning sections a little more streamlined.

It's a decent enough story, they set up/tease the possibility of a sequel which could be good. It doesn't have ridiculously tedious adventure game style puzzles but still makes you pay attention to what is going on. Overall I would recommend the game to mystery and point-and-click fans who want something a little different.

reviewText:
Really enjoyed it. The acting was great, the story was interesting, the puzzles made sense. The central mechanic of finding inconsistencies in people’s stories works pretty well. It’s so much more enjoyable than QTEs, minigames or the typical adventure game thing of collecting random items and combining them in weird ways.

The one thing I didn’t like is the way you have to keep revisiting the same locations over and over again just to see if anything has changed. This repetitive process pads out the length of the game considerably.

Two of the hardest contradictions to spot (for me) were at the very end of the game, so I’d say it’s pretty well balanced difficulty-wise. By the way, if you do get badly stuck, but don’t want to cheat, I’d recommend rewatching the cutscenes: at least two of the contradictions rely on remembering minor details you could have easily forgotten about if you’re not playing the game in one sitting.

reviewText:
This is a FMV detective & mystery game developed by Baggy Cat, created thanks to a kickstarter campaign. Since I love detective games and tv-shows I decided to give this one a go. This is a lovecrafted masterpiece, great from start to finish. I'm gonna try to explain why.

You play as detective Jenks, investigating a girls suicide in an english village. Mysteries surrounding the suicide quickly leads to a murder investigation. Jenks only have a day to solve the mystery. He quickly finds out about a private school for adults called Atlas that uses some questionable methods, and you learn more and more as you go. Every chapter is an hour in the game, but every chapter took me more then an hour each. It's a pretty tricky game, but you can use clues if you get stuck.

You interview people that live in the area and find clues. You look for contradiction, opposites, that a character has said and use that against him/her. It's very exciting and satisfying when you prove that someone is lying.The FMV is very nicely done, captured with HD cameras and different view-angles. They re-used a lot of footage for the enviroment and moving, but added filter to it once it got later at night, a quite smart technique actually. It's made by a small studio with limited resorces after all.

Jenks is very funny, and he really acts out. You will smile a lot during the dialougues. Don't get me wrong though, the voice actors did a great job. Most of the characters are very serious, so it's kinda nice that Jenks mixes it up a little with some humor. The best actor is the boss at Atlas, he is an old grumpy man with some great lines.

You can also find the FMV game on IMDB, if you want to see the list of actors. Score is at 8,9/10, which is a really high score, but I think Contradiction deserves it. I looked up some of the actors and they have been doing lots of movies and shows before. They feel believable which is of course important in a game like this. I could never figure out who the killer was until the end, and the plot was great.

I won't spoil anything, but let me just say that the ending is kinda open for a sequel. Yes, you do get a satifying story from beginning to end, but there is some loose ends that scream for a sequel. Things that weren't investigated enough, characters that obviously had more to them. I looked at the forums and comments on the internet and it seems like everyone just wants more, a follow-up game. It really hope so too, because I really like these sorts of games.

There was some spooky moments in the game, or somewhat creepy at least. It added to the mystery in a nice way and it keept me playing until the end. The old english village with stone houses, lots of wierd things going on and with a bunch of intrigues between the characters just gave me that murder in midsomer"-vibe. You know

reviewText: Very enjoyable murder mystery adventure game with high production value, good cinematography, a strong story, and genuinely excellent acting.  The game has a novel problem solving engine which involves identifying contradictions in individual character statements.  The interface was a bit unusual, and took some time to get used to, but was also weirdly satisfying once the routines sunk in.  The story is compelling and the characters have the right balance of richness dimensionality for a story of this kind.  A couple complaints would be that the storyline itself has some small internal inconsistencies, which are not identified as contradictions within the gameplay.  This proved to be mildly frustrating at times.  The other complaint would be that the process of finding contradictions only took place character-by-character and not across characters (unless it happened to come up in that context).  This made the game more manageable as a puzzler, and still satisfying.  But there were times when characters would say contradictory things with respect to each other, and there was no way to cross examine suspects and access those kind of conversation threads.  Nevertheless, I strongly recommend it for those who enjoy neat, self-contained, story-driven mystery adventure games.

reviewText:
I'm very glad to see the full video adventure games making a come back, thanks to the technology we now have for the actual data storage means and thanks to less expensive video cameras and such. These full video games had emerged eons ago with the CD storage but quickly died because of being terribly expensive to film and because the CD storage wasn't good enough; videos weren't compressed or anything and quickly filled a cd with barely anything. 5 CDs games were legions and were quickly  hated for being cumbersome and annoying to use. Now thanks to a better technology the videos won't rip your eyes out as they did in the past (interlaced mode videos were deadly! ^^) and they can feature more than one hour of filming. And with the digitalized era, we don't have to fiddle with the numerous CDs or DVDs or anything anymore; a couple of clicks on Steam and you're set! Yes, a game all filmed is terribly kitsch but it will have better characters - you do relate more to human beings than to pixels after all.

Contradiction have a good story, even though it's rather classical it's really well told and unfolded brilliantly. It has good characters and the gameplay of spotting the contradictions is quite effective and fun! Of course it will be a bit harder for non-English native players but it's still doable - if I did it, anyone can lol. The music is good. The game settings slowly going from day to night is clever and effective. The game lasted 7 hours and it was really a fun ride!

In the forum the dev talked about making another similar game, I can't wait! More, please!!

reviewText:
I was one of the original Kickstarter backers for this game, as I loved the idea and premise.  Have to say, I wasn't disappointed!  For the low price you get 5-6 hours of good solid adventuring, which will test your cognative skills.  Although spotting most of the contradictions are fairly straightforward, one or two will get your brain in gear.  The FMV sequences are done very well, and the acting is a high standard.

The only slight downside is sometimes navigating the map can be a little tiresome, and you will wish you could just quick jump to a location rather than having to traverse the entire map, but this is a minor niggle in an otherwise great gaming experience.

Here's looking forward to the next installment, as the ending leaves many unanswered questions that I now also want to get to the bottom of.

reviewText:
Full motion video was quite the rage for a brief time in the mid 90's. Outside of Tex Murphy though few developers got it right. Contradiction brings back everything that was good about FMV gaming while avoiding most if not all of its negatives. For a low budget game this has very good acting and a fairly polished and easy to use interface. There is just something very appealing about getting to play the detective and this story has a lot of interesting clues and sub plots that keep you driving to a solution. The basic gameplay premise works very well. Collect clues, interview subjects and spot contradictions in their testimony. This is much more challenging than you would think as you end up with a large amount of testimony from several suspects throughout the 7 to 8 hour experience and finding the contradictions as you get towards the end can be very challenging. You also end up with a large number of red herrings that can distract you from what is important in the information you uncover. There are a couple of hint systems available in the game, but it's very satisfying to work through the testimony on your own to find the solution.

Pros:
HD quality video and solid acting
Smooth interface that is easy to navigate once you get the key commands down.
Backtracking is helped by map that allows you to quickly return to locations
Very interesting mystery that keeps you pushing towards the solution

Cons:
Audio is a bit over compressed causing it to be tinny. Hopefully this is fixed in a later update.
Story ends with many of the subplots unresolved, but open to a possible sequel.
Controller support broken on Windows currently.

You will have to backtrack and speak to suspects over and over as you unlock more clues. This part does have some of the downsides of old 90’s games, but I enjoyed Inspector Jenks so much I didn’t mind and was willing to overlook this. Also, over the course of the many in game hours of interviews the suspects will mostly be in the same places. Drinks will stay the same level and suspects will stare into the same fireplaces. This can take you a bit out of the experience, but I’m sure all the dialog was recorded at the same time and this was necessary for the game design.

Overall this is one of the best FMV and Mystery titles ever made and is quite the achievement on the very small budget the game was made with. I can only hope the game does well enough to make a sequel possible. Game is well worth the asking price.

reviewText:
Contradiction is a rather unique game that uses full-motion-video to tell an intriguing murder mystery story, where you play the detective and have to not only spot the other characters lying, but actually catch them at it with their own words. The game gets off to a slow start as you rapidly figure out the interface and game conventions, but the initial world to explore is quite small with only a couple of characters which the game slowly widens and adds to as you call out the characters on their lies.

The writing and acting are superb, which really helps bring you into the story, and the sense of achievement when you spot the contradictions is great because the script is intelligent and doesn't dumb things down. The quaint British village setting and the cult/occult storyline make you think of classic British TV.

Only real criticism so far is that sometimes the audio for the actors speaking is a touch distorted. This isn't enough to detract from the gameplay and more of the pointer to the producers so that when they make their next game (yes - this is more than good enough to warrant a number of sequels) they're able to improve on this aspect. The in-game music fits the setting perfectly and has just the right amount of creepiness, adding much to the atmosphere!

More!

reviewText:
This was really a ton of fun.  I was a bit wary at first because I was afraid you wouldn't really be doing very much actual playing, but the contradictions are so fun to dig out and it always feels like an accomplishment to exult in when you catch someone in a lie.  It really is one of the best games I've played this year and it has left me satisfied but still wanting more.  I'm very excited to see a sequel.

It does have its weak points, but most mystery plots do.  You will find yourself yelling at characters to notice things that seem so obvious but they totally ignore.  But if it can happen to Sherlock I can forgive them a bit.  It did not take away from the enjoyment for me at all.

The acting is spot on.  If you like British television, especially their mysteries, or really any sort of whodunnit style entertainment then this will be right up your alley.  It has all the intrigue with a hint of the macabre lurking around every corner.  There are campy characters who you will find yourself laughing out loud at constantly and ones with such gravitas that you actually find yourself shrinking back in your seat in intimidation.

So yeah, this is well worth the $10 and the 6-8 hours of your time for a playthrough.  I would not say there is much in terms of replay value, but I did finish with 96% completion and am really curious to see what I missed.  I would love for them to allow you to go back and conduct interviews after the finale just so you can try to find that elusive contradiction.

reviewText:
What a great wee gem of a game. The original generation of FMVs are a bit before my time, but I understand that the tech often didn't live up to the ambition. Well, that one's more area where grasp has now caught up to vision. The video works beautifully with well-chosen angles and smooth movement between shots. The characters are well-cast and well-rounded - it feels like an interactive BBC drama - and the contradiction game play works really well. The setting feels genuinely eerie and tense without being heavy-handed, and the ominous atmosphere only built as the sun went down (lovely touch, by the way). It's challenging enough to cause some head-scratching without becoming completely frustrating (see the Steam walkthrough if you need it - the cheats function doesn't appear to work). The game's plot kep me guessing, tying the main investigation up at the end while creating an intriguing world that I hope will be built upon in further installments.

There are a couple of things Pneuma could do to improve. Auto-playing the prologue video when the game starts would help set the scene for the player. As it is currently, you just land in front of the pub feeling a little confused. A run through of the controls at the start would also benefit the game. I was told to use the 'investigation' and the 'inventory' buttons by text boxes, however, there had been no explanation what these were ('s' and 'enter'). That said, there are control instructions on the Menu screen so it's easy enough to figure out. Going back to the Prologue Video, there's a fair bit of unnecessary exposition. In the next game I'd cut this down to scene-setting only and let the game do the rest of the work (which it does, very well). Last point, a couple of the scenes where Jenks attempts to assert his authority felt a little silly. A bit more research into police descalation techniques would help remedy this.

All of the above are just suggested improvements and don't detract from the fact that I enjoyed playing this game a lot. So much so, I completed it in a single sitting (lovely way to spend Sunday). I look forward to returning to the world of Contradiction and finding out more about the clandestine workings of the Atlas Institute.

reviewText:
Literally one of the best games I've played this year.

It was my first FMV ever and I randomly found this out while browsing through detective games on Steam. It was a great surprise.
First off, the cast is outstanding. Amazing actors and brilliant performances, they really help the narrative a lot and make everything interesting. Then the media quality is good as well, since videos are in full HD. Characters are just awesome: they could literally be all killers and that's what makes the plot interesting, since it's really hard to understand what happened until the very end.

I have to admit that sometimes the game is a bit repetitive, especially in the mid-part of the story: if you are not particularly expert in puzzle games, you'll most likely end up stuck in a boring loop of: find a clue-talk to everybody- find a clue - talk to everybody -and so on. But maybe it's just me being stupid.

Overall, absolutely recommended, totally worth its price. (I've paid its cd key 0.89 $, but it's full Steam price still seems totally fair to me).

reviewText:
Contradiction is a minimally funded (via Kickstarter) live action (or if you're old school, FMV) point-and-click adventure that you should buy and play so they can make a sequel.  The end.

Okay, so without giving anything away, the game is mostly about listening to suspect interviews and trying to find contradictory statements.  There is minimal use of the traditional adventure item inventory. If you have no interest in the backtracking, reviewing conversations, or getting stuck that is typical of the last 30 years of adventure gaming, stop reading, because this game won't convince you to like those things.

However, if you are still reading, there are only two questions worth considering for whether you should play this game.  Is the acting too cheesy to tolerate, and does it play well as an adventure? As for the acting, I enjoyed it.  The casting is good, the voices are good, and only the main character (the inspector you play) is heavily overacting, but in the most endearing way possible.  Of course realize that I am predisposed to enjoy the genuine British accents and setting, so without that bias, you may not fall as heavily in love with these actors as I did.  You've got some believable ladies, and several appropriately disturbing gentlemen, one of whom stands by a mantelpiece and channels a smarmy Tim Curry while the other sits in a comfy chair and does a condescending Ian McDiarmid.

As for gameplay, I was able to finish (and 100% the game with no cheats) in a couple of days amounting to maybe seven or eight hours without ever getting maddeningly stuck.  Regarding gameplay, here's my breakdown.

The so-so:

You backtrack a lot.
There aren't many locations and only a handful of items of very limited use.
Due to the nature of the writing, you will think of tons of connections that you can't inquire about.
You can only get further info on contradictions (see the name) and no other connections.
You can't inquire about statements from two different characters that contradict each other, only the self-contradictory statements.
The scenes aren't really reshot for different times, just put through a blue filter for darkness (wait, that's not a gameplay element).
There are typos.

The good:

None of the contradictions are impossible to spot, but only a few are totally obvious.
It's satisfying to find a contradiction because you noticed something visual in the scene that isn't really stated in the summaries you choose from. The statements that act as inventory items are helpful enough, but a keen eye helps too.
There are options for hints and cheats, although I didn't use them.
Calls to the police chief serve to summarize where you stand in the case without acting as cheats.
There is no lore-reading necessary.  All of the story is fully acted out or recounted through live interviews.
The feeling of progress is extremely satisfying, and the advancing of hours acts as milestones.
There are red herrings everywhere, which creates a believable atmosphere, fully fleshed out.

I've played a lot of adventure games since the 80s, and I think you should play this one, even at full price.

Pretty solid FMV game.  You basically interview a few different people about a murder.  As you interview them you discover more information.  The goal of the game is to catch people in lies, which then advances the game's progress and reveals more clues.  Eventually you solve the case.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Buy this excellent detective adventure game so that we can have more!

Full motion video (FMV) game, huh? That's a blast from the past, this one funded by a kickstarter of mere 4000 £. There were many FMV games in the 90s though I only remember playing Terra Nova and Command & Conquer franchise with their acted interludes. One problem with them was the huge space and computing power requirements of video and it still looked pretty bad. Large-volume hard discs, speedy downloads and technological advances in computation make those problems go away and you are left with problems of writing, acting, shooting and editing. This being a game, the gameplay is also important. So how're those things holding up for Contradiction?

In the game you are a police investigator. Remember all those detective stories they show reruns of in the afternoons? This is like a single, long episode of that, with you doing the actual deducing and detective work. Well, you embodying the detective of stereotypical looks, Mr. Jenks. He has been sent to check this little Twin Peaksy town somewhere in England (I presume), because someone there has died under suspicious circumstances involving a suicide claim, a creepy business school and alcohol.

Our protagonist seems to be a tad old-fashioned, as he goes around asking questions and generally snooping around the town. The main game mechanism is to review the statements people give you and then call any contradictions you might find in their answers. Now let me say it: this is the coolest aspect of the game! We had tremendous amount of fun and frustration alike trying to spot the one or two contradictions in the rather large amount of statements. Some of them are dead obvious, while others are sneaky as a still animal in a forest: hiding in plain sight but hidden by the vegetation. Sometimes you even have to listen their statements again to get that piece of missing information.

Speaking of forest again, this broke us to a small inside joke that I'll give out here as a tip: if you don't know what to do, go to the woods because random ♥♥♥♥ happens in the woods and sometimes that's the only way to go forward. This is because to ask questions you got to have questions and you could find additional evidence in all kinds of places. In addition to exploration the progression sometimes involves minor puzzle solving like using items in correct places but nothing fancier than that.

Story is all paced through one busy evening, during which you meet the quirky locals: various students, misfits and businessmen and -women. Everyone seems to know more than they are letting out. Acting is nice despite the actors being fairly unknown. Editing has been done very well, movement between places by video feels fluid and quite natural. I am not totally sure if Mr. Jenks' actor was taking it seriously though as his actor could be described as rather expressive": he was making surprised and curious faces all the time

reviewText:
FMV games are an unknown territory for me as a genre, especially since my younger self did not have access to them during the phase of its fad-like popularity. Looking at previous titles however makes me wonder if it truly was ever popular, as many FMV titles seemed to be all about the technology and visual wow factor rather than the gameplay or story-telling aspects. Contradiction must be familiar with this trend as it shirks the all style, shallow substance method, and instead brings an engaging story with a varied, likable cast who’s performances only add to the experience as you progress along the game... Even if most of said performances are outright the most bizarre, silly examples of acting I’ve ever seen. (It’s a good thing, really.)

Contradiction is set entirely within and around the limits of the sleepy British village of Edenton, and has the player character, Inspector Jenks, investigating the apparent suicide of a resident. There’s a pseudo time limit to complete the case, but each passing hour acts like a chapter, rather than pressure to hustle you along. Being an adventure game, hopping around the different areas will reveal potential clues to pick up, events revealing new characters, or more information on your current suspects once your leads have run dry. Jenks’ journal at first has only a handful of clues and subjects, but getting your gumshoe on will eventually have a plethora of possible lines of questioning (and a few red herrings, to be expected) to use on people of interest. Most of your time will be spent interviewing the various Edenton residents with said collection of clues, and unlocking more subjects in the process. This is where Contradiction’s gameplay lies, as you might expect in a game based on police investigation, people end up lying or trying to mislead you, and Jenks must use their testimony against them by taking two statements to reveal a titular contradiction, and break the witness’ lie to get the truth - Or more fibbing. Rinse and repeat until the game is over. While this sounds like it would become mighty old in a mighty hurry, the actors and their performances is what keeps the game engaging right to the closing credits... Not because of sheer brilliance that should be reserved for Broadway, but because of the sheer campy, humorous way in which things take place.

I wonder if the director is secretly a mad genius, since the acting can get so silly at times yet remain so believable that it’s both comical and interesting how characters won’t react or call out each others quirks, save for moments of intense emotion. I will confess my expertise on live action acting is severely lacking in order for me to truly explain performances, but look up some videos and you’ll begin to understand what I mean. The way Simon (Magnus Sinding) seems to act sketchy and suspicious after nearly every question he answers, the way Rebecca (Melanie Gray) hardly budges in her seat and speaks like she is in ownership of an evil spy empire, how Ryan (John Guilor) cannot help but speak and gesture like he is always trying to impress, and his posh-ness makes it impossible not to giggle at him constantly. And of course there’s Jenks (Rupert Booth), who’s wild eyes, head bobs and expressions make me wonder if it’s a police tactic to seem a bit weird in order to lower the guard of witnesses. I am certain that if the actors played the script straight and with the severity that the story had, this would be a much tamer if not duller experience. The campy acting may not be for everyone, but I can only applaud the actors and director for allowing the goofiness to run rampant and free, entertaining the player more for it.

After the praises I have previously sung, my complaints against Contradiction are quite minor, and are generally tied to the menus. At some point, you will end up with a lot of clues and subjects to sift through, which can be an annoyance when looking for two specific statements to use as contradiction fodder. You’re given a master list of testimony to thumb through everyone’s answers regarding a certain clue which is nice and all, but the game follows a very tight script on what is and is not a contradiction, and the script doesn’t budge for lesser lies. Things that should feel contradictory are ignored, as the game only wants the big, apparent lies to be revealed to keep the intrigue and story going. Still, it’s quite satisfying when Jenks finds a contradiction, as he goes from generally friendly and approachable to snarky, sarcastic and borderline demeaning once he catches someone in a lie, and watching the witness squirm is only icing on that cake.

I like Contradiction a whole bunch. The acting is wonderfully nutty, the story is dark yet becomes very engaging as more is revealed regarding the secrets of Atlas and the skeletons in everyone’s closets, and one can see their way to the end in about five or six hours. I can give it a hearty recommendation for anyone looking for a story driven adventure game, but those who want a seriously written script may want to look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Contradiction was a really interesting game. It definitely had that old school point and click vibe going on, but mostly I was reminded of Phoenix Wright. The investigation segments, and of course the interviews were a lot like cross examining a witness, listening to their statements and presenting them with evidence to the contrary. The story is fascinating. There's so much going on in that small town, this game barely scratches the surface. The acting is pretty good. Paul Rand is spot-on as a cold, methodical character. Inspector Jenks is a clever guy. Everyone settles into their role well, giving the game a good feel.

The soundtrack was good. It was never too invasive, and during some of the interview segments it really served to puncutate statements well. Visually, it's all live action. Some people might gripe that later on in the game as it gets close to midnight, it's really not as dark as it should be outside, but I would argue that what they chose to do for those times is better because you can actually see what's going on, something that I imagine would have been much harder had they filmed at night.

I'd like to see this game get a sequel. There's just so much more to touch on with Atlas, and the Rands. I hope it gets the funding it needs.

reviewText:
Contradiction was a very enjoyable game, not only for me but for viewers on my Twitch stream as well. The story itself started out interesting enough to catch my interest, and the further we dove into it the better it got. The acting was awkward and cheesy, which you're either going to love or hate. Personally I enjoyed it, it was all very charming.

The actual gameplay was interesting, but could get frustrating. Towards the end of the game I felt the clues and category of clues got a bit much, and could make it difficult to find specific statements to make a contradiction with. The difficulty was spot on for me. We had some frustrating moments in the beginning, trying to find the contradiction, but in the end it felt fair and just right. Unlike other people, I'm glad the game had no QTEs or other gameplay features tacked on to provide more involvement for the player.

The mystery was very captivating, and if there was anything this game lacked it was tying together a few more loose ends. While you do end up solving the objective of the game, it leaves you with many more questions than when you started the game. If we do end up getting a sequel for this game, I will without a doubt buy it and play it.

If you enjoy FMV games, mystery solving, or just want to kick back with a laid back story I would definitely recommend it. The price tag is fair, if you ask me.

reviewText:
The premise of this game was great, unfortunately it wasnt executed as well as it could have been.

For what appears to be made on a small budget, I cant really fault the acting, even though 1 character appeared to be nursing the same drink for at least 4 hours, only to spill it late in the game. THE FOOL!
The characters were a strong point for the game, even if the acting sometimes fell short. Jenks was intelligent, calm and occasionally humorous. The rest of the cast appeared to have depth and real individual personalitles.
At times it was a little frustrating as information i wanted to further investigate was brushed aside immediately after it was revealed. I also took exception to not being able to ask certain questions to avoid upsetting a character, i couldnt imagine a real detective sparing the feelings of possible suspects while attemepting to solve a possible murder.
There were times that you would notice a contradiction between two characters but be unable to follow that obvious line of questioning. it was almost like them giving you vital clues but then shaking keys in front of your eyes as a distraction so you didnt solve the case too quick. It made the game feel as though you were looking for clues to progress the story and not looking for clues to solve the case. Kind of like being shown a giant tender steak cooked to perfection, with roasted vegetables and a small amount of mushroom gravy on the side but forcing you to eat multiple entrees made up of non delicious fillers, before sinking your teeth into that juicy rare steak.

Using the map as a fast travel can stagnate your progress as walking through certain areas at times will trigger events that you may otherwise not travel to. They regualrly feel unimportant to your progress.
Without revealing spoilers, the story couldve been rearranged in a fashion to make it fit together more smoothly instead of feeling like you've ignored vital pieces of information.
I also feel that the game could have benefitted hugely from flashbacks.  I wouldve loved a chance to get to know the victim through story driven flashbacks as important  information was revealed. Maybe this was a budget issue for them and it was something they were just unable to include, which is understandable.

It was a fun FMV detective game. But some small adjustments couldve improved the immersion immensly. mainly the organisation of the story and how in the timeline you were given certain bits of information.
It really feels like they have opened some interesting oppurtunities if a second game was to be created.

Overall it was an enjoyable game with potential to become a fun series, especially on the back of Inspector Jenks.
While i do reccommend it, I do so hesitantly. I've attempted to explain what i found to be frustrating with the game and hopefully help you to make an informed decision before purchasing.

reviewText:
Just finished this excellent game!
Really nice style throughout. The mystery kept me guessing, the video environments were detailed, and the acting was great. :)
There is a slight bug with the interface - namely sometimes you stop being able to click exit when talking to people, or you can't select contradictions, or the direction buttons disappear. This is irritating, but in every case I was able to either replay a video and then the controls would come back, navigate away using the map button, or exit and start again. So yes, it's annoying, but it's not a game-killer.
I liked the method of the blue filter to make things feel more like night time as the game progressed. It would have been good to have something similar inside, though - it was a bit strange with some midnight scenes being shot in daylight.
Those are really minor, minor things though. Just tips for improvement on the next one.
Very good game with an original, Midsomer Murders (or Barnaby" in Europe) style. Love it!"

With a mere ~$6000 Kickstarter budget, Contradiction accomplishes beautifully what L.A. Noire couldn't pull off with ~$48 million:  a spot-the-lie detective story where the contradictions are actually contradictions.

If you want running, jumping, headshots, open worlds, experience grinding, leveling up, skill-trees, and loot (all of which I love immensely), look elsewhere.

If you want an easily-accessible, story-driven mystery game where you can sit back with a friend or two and brainstorm together about whose story doesn't quite add up, this game is worth every penny.

Altogether, about 8-12 hours long (depending on how quickly you work it out).

Will definitely be buying any game like this that the developer makes in the future.
This game was very well thought through, beautifully shot and exicuted. Overall a very easy purchase and fun experience.

Good game and lots of fun good to have a cup of tea with a snack. It did get a tad too... lucky a  times with the main character just happening to be there when keys were dropped... lots of keys being dropped lol. Still I enjoyed it.

So refreshing to play a game with actual actors.  They do a pretty good job too.  A relaxing but interesting little mystery.  I hope they do make another.  I hope the controller support is a little more solid next time too.  This would've been nice to play over Steam Link with my Steam Controller, but it didn't quite work out.

As a fan of L.A. Noire's (unsurpassed imho) facial capture system used during interrogations, I liked this alternative format of interviewing suspects. As long as you are prepared for what a FMV-heavy game is, you'll find a lot to enjoy here. The lead character you control overacts to the Nth degree, so its worth watching just to see what he does in every scene he’s in.\n\nI was surprised to see some of the names involved in this game, including Tim Follin, who should be well-known to anyone familiar with 8-bit chip tunes. reviewText: Just finished Contradiction. It a great game. Good story.\nThere is a bug that can make the buttons not work so save regularly.

I haven't yet finished, but I spent three hours playing it last night with a friend. We used a voice chat and both had a copy of the game, so we just chose to go to the same areas at the same time and notify each other on options to click. It's been a ridiculous amount of fun. There's a distinct satisfaction in discovering that contradiction and seeing the text go green. The acting of Jenks IS over the top and sometimes threw me out of the story. He was wonderfully hammy and it wasn't horrible though. So while I comment on the acting, I also almost feel it was charming. The cast in general acted very well and I felt genuinely intimidated by one particular character even though he was somewhat stereotypical villain. They did a good job of rewarding falling back to check areas you've already been to. Overall, it's been a ton of fun and the only real qualm I have about it is sometimes the music got too loud... even when I had ambient music turned off so that it wouldn't echo in my chat with my friend.

Honestly, considering how much fun it is to play with another friend, I'd love it if any future games like this considered some sort of chat integration or way to ease playing together rather than just timing it. But that's a minor thing. Mystery fans should definitely check this game out!

Edit: Just finished the game and it was excellent all the way through. Completely set up for a sequel, which if it's on Kickstarter again I hope I hear about it!

This game was so freaking good!\nI have rarely played a narrative based game that grabbed your attention so well and kept it through the whole thing! The idea is basic, but brilliant. Listen to the testimonies people give and then catch them when they give you contradictory statements. The pacing is great, because you're given the time to work out the mystery before the plot starts moving along. I'm only sad that I can only play through a game like this once, but it was one hell of a ride!\nThis is a glorious return of the FMV adventure genre! I am so pumped for more! Why isn't there a kickstarter for the second game already?!

Given that this game was made on a tiny budget and sold for a cost that turns out, I believe to be excellent value for $, the quality of work is very high indeed.  I'm very interested in seeing a sequel, and hope there are enough mystery buffs out there like myself that feel the same so it will happen.\n\nSide note: I love Jenks, he's a very amusing character that reminded me of some of my favorite Dr. Who characters in recent history with his mannerisms & enthusiasm for his job.

This is an amazing movie styled game, all the characters are entertaing and great to watch! If there is a sequel to this game I would definatly get it ;) The whole catching people in their lies is quiet fun and makes you think and try to remember a lot :P But all in all a really good game and I highly recommend it!
If you enjoy Phoenix Wright and visual novels with a mystery flair, this game is for you. It gives good depth of character, excellent atmosphere, and good conversational puzzles to figure out.

BUY THIS GAME! It's worth it.

An amazingly acted FMV with interesting characters and an eccentric detective that reminds me of British shows. reviewText:
After hearing about this game in some of the Giant Bomb Game of the Year podcasts, I quickly bought it and played through it in 2 sittings.

It took me about 6 hours to complete, although I did peek at the community forums a few times when I was stuck. Overall it was an enjoyable experience. The fact that it is all video based makes it a really unique game and definitely caused me to keep playing through some of the parts where I got stuck.

There is a tease of a sequel at the end, which I would love to play as well.

Played this through with my roomate. Took about seven hours with the two of us thinking on everything, no cheats used. It's a wonderful challenge, and none of it particularly unfair; often with these kinds of games you get into a situation where you're lost in the verbage, trying to figure out which exact lines the game wants you to choose, even if it's not the most logical. This game doesn't suffer from that at all, and we were generally able to single out the exact choices we had to make when hit with inspiration.

Acting is spot-on; my only real complaint is about how jarringly hammy the lead detective is, but it's so over-the-top that it eventually becomes strangely endearing. Might not be that way for everyone, but I've come to love Jenks' great facial expressions.

The ending leaves ample room for a much larger sequel, and I hope the devs are able to fund it. At $10, this game is a ♥♥♥♥ing STEAL and it's one of the better detective-type games on Steam right now.

Would highly recommend to fans of detective shows, detective fiction, and fans of Danganronpa and Phoenix Wright who need their fix between games.

A good game to play with another person (even somone not nessessarily interested in games) an interesting storydriven game. The game does however have faults perhaps due to the tight budgets occasionally some things that seem like valid contradictions are not accepted by the game and do not advance the plot. It is not always obvious what you have to do next you can ask for a hint but the answers often seem unrelated to the dialogue/line of enquiry you are persuing.

That being said the story is engaging and it is a fun game that doesnt take itself to seriously. The actors seem to have enjoyed the roles and their entusiasum for the characters is infectious.

Also I played this on an eight year old pc running vista so perhaps the system requirements are more forgiving than suggested.

A really wonderful and fantastic game, with a heaping helping of hilarious cheese. The main premise of the game is to investigate the accidental(?) death of a young woman in a small town, but mysteries quickly pile on and turn into more mysteries, as your character interviews people left and right (some of them high as a kite) and turning up increasingly bizarre pieces of evidence.

The real meat of the game is the interviews -- you have to actually pay attention to what people are saying and try to catch them in a lie. It's super fun, as most games tend to lead you around by the nose these days. It's also quite difficult at times, especially when your list of topics and suspects grows longer and longer and you have a hard time determining what is a lie versus a merely ambiguous statement. Rarely, though, I would discover someone had made a clear contradiction, only to have the game dismiss it, but it only happened two or three times the entire game.

This is honestly the most fun I've had with a game in a long, long time. I played it with my significant other, and we had a million times more fun deducing (and occasionally laughing) together than we would have if we'd played it apart. This game is worth it at full price.

I've been on an FMV kick lately and had a lot of fun with this game. The acting, for the most part, is surprisingly good, especially for a game with this kind of budget. It was a little campy or goofy at times (especially Inspector Jenks) but that is part of the fun for me.

The gameplay itself is pretty simple, basically just spot the lie by matching up contradictory statements from people around town. No major bugs, but I did have an issue with replaying previous videos I would have to force quit the game afterwords as it wouldn't let me click any of the menu items afterwards. Annoying, for sure, but not a deal breaker.

All in all I enjoyed this and it's definitely worth the $10.

reviewText:
A very fun experience. The actor playing Jenks kept the entire story light and fun despite the dark connotations of the events. He might have gone a bit too far with silly faces from time to time but honestly it was refreshing and entertaining given nonstop wicked overtones.

Pros
The acting is well done for such a small budget, Jenks is straight up wacky in some scenes and calm and reflective in others. I cant imagine he takes his job too seriously. Its a shame because I feel like there are some specific scenes where acting more like a professional and being more concerned for his personal safety would add to the character rather then feel disjointed.
The musical score was very involved as well, gave a nonstop air of foreboding that really helped to set the mood and atmosphere of the game. It also sounded like the major plot points and reveals happened to often coincide with heavy piano notes being played. Could be my imagination but I think that it was done intentionally.

Cons
The interface was a bit jarring at first until you got used to it, various topics would highlight as green while others stayed blue but this didnt actually translate to any hints or topics you should try to converse next. It felt random and led to lots of extra time spent re-exploring topics that werent needed to find contradictions that didnt exist
You will find dozens of things that people say that are contradictory by definition that dont lead to cutscenes, this can be  frustrating over time as you feel that you caught a person in their lies but the payoff never results of actually discussing it with them. Likely this was an error of budget contraints or logical omissions in the games story and script. Either way I would highly encourage the developement team to either include cutscenes for each of these in future games, or more carefully write the dialog so that we dont spend half the game pouring over linking contradictions that aren't intended by the developer.

reviewText:
Contradiction: Spot The Liar! - A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good
Smooth transitions between videos and menus
Some good acting
Compelling mystery story
The not so good:
The UI. “Press Enter to exit. Press Enter to Ask” were both on screen at the same time.
Some porn level acting…hmm..*Kyle*
The game is unplayable with a controller plugged into the PC.
The conclusion:
Is this the start of a new FMV golden era? Don’t know for sure, but C:STL! does a great job reintroducing this genre to the new generation. Technically, I don’t know how they made transitions so smooth, but it was a pleasure to play. Even though it becomes repetitive at one point, it didn’t become annoying. If they manage to address the controller issue and make the UI more user friendly, this could be a pretty solid game. If you enjoy mysteries and yearn for that LA Noir vibe, this is a must buy.
You can see me playing  the first chapter here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x524kC7bbtA

reviewText:
There are two reasons I can't recommend this game.

1) It seems the game designer is not a very good game designer, just a good writer and director. You are supposed to be an investigator, but you can't really do things an investigator should be able to do. If you ask two people about the same subject and you know one of them is lying, you can't really see a contradiction between dialogues of different people. You also can't investigate for yourself. It claims to be a point-and-click, but all you do is click on a magnifying glass and Jenks do all the job for you (not very nice for a game...). Basically, the game is about talking with people and just waiting for them to lie about something (because none of them are very good liars).

2) The ending. It is the most disappointing ending in any murder mystery investigation game. If this was a real-life investigation and I was the investigator, I would probably solve the case in 20 minutes, but apparently Jenks takes 7 hours to do so because he's either lazy or clueless about clear evidence.
---KIND OF SPOILERS AHEAD---
Basically, there's an unique tape on the victim's driver's license (you can see at the trailer). I noticed it right away and early on the game Jenks comes across the same tape on window. However, this is not presented as a clue (even though it would clearly be something a real detective would notice and use as evidence). Anyway, this would not bother me if this particular tape was not the only thing that actually frames the killer. Near the ending, the tape comes across as important again, and when you ask the killer about it, he or she just confesses the crime. This to me is just the most stupid thing.

TL;DR
If you want a good point-and-click mystery game, look for some of Nancy Drew's games. They're way better in gameplay and mystery plot.

I would love to recommend this game, I really do.

I fully played it over the last few days and really enjoyed it. The story is interesting, the characters are varied and fun, the gameplay is easy to grasp without much explanation. Some of the acting can be a bit campy depending on the characters, though I personally find this pretty entertaining.

I also have to warn you that this game's ending is a bit open-ended and has a sequel hook. It's not really a cliffhanger, but if you want your games wrapped up neatly with no questions left unanswered, you'll have to look elsewhere.

If the interface issues don't bother you, don't mind to regularly save manually using the two save slots and have no qualms with endings that don't give full closure on every detail, I think you can safely buy it, though.

reviewText:
The original makers of FMV games had valid excuses for releasing terrible products--the video game industry was small, the medium was in its infancy, and the technology of the time severely limited what was possible.

Contradiction makes the mistake of thinking that being terrible was not a result of the circumstances early FMV games were developed in, but an integral part of the genre. It seems to have been developed by somebody with only the most basic understanding of what video games even are, and no understanding of what makes them fun. The technical and design issues alone are numerous and baffling. Sometimes you can use the mouse, sometimes only the keyboard. Controls can only be configured by going to the menu and setting them all up in a row, and can't be set individually. There are inscrutable menu options you can't use. When navigating around town, forward becomes back and back becomes forward, based on whatever room you were in previously, but with no change in perspective to indicate it. A single button is shared for both inventory" and "use".

Hear me out: I'm not complaining because I went to a silent movie and there was no sound. I'm complaining because I went to a silent movie and the director thought it would only be an authentic 1920s experience if he also gave me polio."

Contradiction - Spot The Liar! has no controller support, even though the Store Page lists partial controller support as a feature.  Partial controller support would have been helpful, but there is absolutely no controller support whatsoever.

Due to the lack of controller support, and the very unintuitive control layout that IS featured, I have no choice but to NOT recommend Contradiction.

Additionally, I have made inquiries within the forums / discussion thread regarding an update to controller support with absolutely no response from the devs or publisher.  Due to the lack of customer service and due to false advertising, I am receiving a full refund through Steam support.

reviewText: Great game for the price. Can't wait for a follow up.

Rather interesting live-action video point and click adventure. The main character's quirkiness and facial expressions were quite amusing, and, overall, I felt that all the actors did a great job in portraying their characters; without spoiling anything, I can say that I am looking forward to more stories starring Inspector Jenks!

With regard to the actual gameplay mechanics I was pleasantly surprised by the lack of a hidden object aspect; the storytelling was well-paced, and no aspect of the tale felt anticlimatic at all (quite the opposite, actually).

I would definitely recommend this game, it reminded me of Dracula Unleashed, another live-action adventure from the 7th Guest era (1993-ish), making it all the more fun. Thumbs up to the developers, will definitely be expecting a sequel!

The world needs more games like this, genuinely brave in times when hype and graphics outweigh entertainment. Cracking storytelling. A no brain purchase, if there is ANYTHING I can do with assisting with a follow-up get in touchI SPREADING THE WORD NOW!!

THE GOOD:
-This is a very clever story that manages to introduce a lot of plot points and red herrings that keep you guessing.
-The characters are authentic and fully developed. The relationships between the characters are intricate and well developed
-The acting and video is very good.
-The story and characters are sophisticated enough that it allows for future games
-There are a lot of non verbal clues - everything in the visual background of the story is relevant - excellent attention to detail


THE BAD
-The user interface is terrible.  It works just enough that you can play the game
-You can only ask characters about their own statements - you can't ask them about the statements of others. This means that a lot of obvious clues could not be acted upon - simply because they had been said by another character in the game
- there is a glaring visual clue toward the beginning of the game that hints at who the killer could be.  It was frustrating to see this clue and not be able to act upon it.

PLAY THE GAME?
My assessment is that enduring the poor interface, and lack of sophistication in gameplay options, is worth it to experience this story and solve the puzzle.

FOR THE FUTURE
It would be fantastic if the game creators could improve their user interface, and also open up the ways that players can interact with the game. Also, whilst there were a respectable number of scene locations, it would be great if there were more.

I look forward to playing future games in this franchise.
