'Contradiction - Spot the Liar' had my attention as soon as I started it. You play as a detective who is inspecting a suicide of a college girl named Girl, who happens to be enrolled in a business course of an organization called Atlas which has all the right amounts of shady. It’s a brilliant setup and is very engrossing. I started playing this with my mom, who had never ever played any sort of video game. She immediately liked it and that’s saying a lot!

Coming to the mechanics, I really loved it. I think it has got its roots from the very famous board game 'Cluedo' and it works on the same principle of questioning the suspects and finding a contradicting statements they have made and so spotting their lies. It’s a really neat mechanic and it meshes in perfectly with this game.

The presentation is well laid out and the menus are easy to traverse. I really loved the little cut scenes which play out when switching between areas but it got a little monotonous in the end and I wished there was an option to skip it. But it’s not a very major gripe that it will keep you from playing the game at all.

Speaking about cut scenes, the main cut scenes are quite enjoyable. Mainly due to the over the top acting of Detective Jenks with his ridiculous outfit, with the more serious acting by the rest of the cast. There were some time where I felt that the acting was not up to the mark but it was negligible. I really enjoyed the acting of Mr. Paul Rynd who had a tone very similar to Professor Snape from the Harry Potter Series.

The story, wow it did grip me all the way from the beginning till the last bit. The ending for me was a letdown, I feel it was rushed and left many questions which I wanted to know unanswered. They introduced a lot of supernatural and horror elements which was fantastic for the brief about of time it lasted, but they shied away from it towards the end. Maybe due to the time restrictions they had to rush the final bits of the game. But I’m sure if they had given more time it would have been a 10/10 experience. This was one of the two issues I had with the game.

The other issue was some of the contradiction puzzles seemed easy, it may also be because I was always in track with all the replies given by each and every suspect for each and every evidence, but some contradictions are very hard to find.

Overall I had a lot of fun playing this game, it kept me hooked throughout until the end bit. They did throw a hint for a sequel in the end which would solve all the mysteries. I hope they manage to come out with it in the future. Finally saying that I do not recommend this game to anyone will be a contradiction itself, so yes go and play this game, its good! I want more of this please!

But the game is brilliant. It feels so amazing when you do get a contridiction. And the video aspect of it is, in my opinion, a better choice than whatever 3d digital world/characters someone could have made. The story was pretty interesting, the characters pretty unique, and I couldn't stop thinking about the game once I started playing.

The ending felt a little weak, and it left some unanswered questions.

I would 100% buy another game like this for around $10-$15. Maybe spend a little more if the game was a little bigger and made by this same company.

The game has a small quaint town filled with moody atmosphere and secrets filmed amazingly in glorious HD. But what got me was using the video to create the 'still' directional screens to show you where to go - added a terrific environmental quality when they could have just used a still image. The acting for this 'low budget' event is actually fantastic, especially Paul and Ryan who had me on the edge of my seat, and of course the detective who I reckon enjoyed every second grilling his costars. Finding items to quiz people is understandably easy as the real crux of the game is trying to finding contradicting evidence in people's testimonies. There are plenty of adventure games where having a large inventory provokes conversation, but this game has managed to use the wonderful performances and nuances of the actors to provide that 'inventory' for you. The game does hint at a sequel but honestly they could create any number of other murder mysteries in other settings that I'd be enormously happy with. Please support this game, burn the pirates, and I hope very soon we see a sequel :) 9.5/10

reviewText: Contradiction is a fun and immersive experience for those who enjoy a FMV-style mystery game. The dialog was really well developed, and the acting was enjoyable. Well worth a try.

I highly recommend this game!

I bought this game solely because Paul Darrow is in it. I wasn’t expecting much from the game. To my delight, Contradiction – Spot the Liar made for an entertaining evening… and late evening… then early morning…  I hooked my pc to the big screen and played along with a house guest who doesn’t play a lot of video games. We were hooked almost from the beginning.

The navigation is simple and reminds me of DVD games. I thought the gameplay would get dull – location, interrogate, repeat, but the pace of clues and strength of the acting kept that from happening. Like most games that rely on questioning suspects, there are questions the player wants to ask that never come up. As this relies on finding contradictions, this does become more of an issue at times, but not to a point that crippled gameplay. There are lots of red herrings or lines of inquiry that go nowhere. I can’t tell you how many times we picked up an item and said “Don’t forget what Simon said about that. That’s important.” only to have nothing happen. Rather than annoy, it left us with a longing for a sequel.

The acting is great. I found Jenks’ shoes and hat a bit annoying, and every time he flourished the evidence at a suspect I expected him to say “Is this your card?”, but it added to his quirkiness. Paul Darrow is great. He brings nuance to the role and is still one of the best “reaction” actors I’ve seen.

The only real downside is replayability. I’d love to get my game night group together to do this, but it won’t be as much fun for me. I’ll still probably do it.

If I were the producers, I’d make a 20 minute playable demo using the existing material and mechanics to help sell this and get money for a sequel on Kickstarter. Something that shows off the ease of interrogation and introduces most of the characters would be a great marketing tool and short enough to share with friends (particularly the non-gamer 40-55 demo who would love this game if they knew it existed).

I really dug this title. I found the mystery intriguing and the gameplay strangely addicting. We'll just need to get a sequel.

reviewText: Excellent. Reminded me of a British Twin Peaks!

Interactive detective movie in a small village. This game was like a breath of fresh air - good concept - very well implemented with good script and slick editing for modest cast - quite fun - best tried with friends or family together with output to TV screen - occasional rare minor interface bugs but easily overcome - some scenes and acting quirky and quaint but all the funnier for that - there is enough for a couple of evenings or one very long one - would fit in with a weekend effort with friends or family nicely.

Was very happy to forgive any minor shortcomings of this game because overall the effort and polish of what was attempted was accomplished very impressively; it is not easy to script, edit, act out and film such a work so well - the developers have done a good job on this - appreciate it and I hope you will enjoy this interactive TV detective show as much as we did.

I picked it up when on a heavily discounted price tag and found it great value entertainment - I don't often review games but this delivered what I was expecting and was fun - deserves support, success and sequels.

Do you enjoy mystery games and might be interested in trying out full-motion video (FMV) games then look no further!

Contradiction is a simple point and click game. You travel back and fourth between various suspects to question about clues that you find or through talking to other suspects. The main aspect that sets Contradiction apart are the full-motion video that feature great actors; my favorites being Jenks and Paul. It does remind me of a beloved series Ace Attorney although it is much more simplified but still enjoyable.

As the entire game is shot in full-motion video, it is a joy to watch and interact with the game. You can really tell when a character is nervous or lying from their acting. The most endearing part is the investigator, Jenks with his comical expressions.

Although this game is quite straightforward and not really a game that you need to replay I think it is still worth playing. I do agree with some that the ending is bittersweet as you slowly uncover deep hidden evils within the settings and characetrs, however I think it is only an encouragement for a sequel that I really hope they will go ahead with. If they end up promoting their sequel onto KickStarter, I know I would love to help fund it.
Very fun game. Would love to see more games like this on larger budgets- this could really improve the overall quality of the acting and the impact of the visuals.

I bought this game solely because Paul Darrow is in it. I wasn’t expecting much from the game. To my delight, Contradiction – Spot the Liar made for an entertaining evening… and late evening… then early morning…  I hooked my pc to the big screen and played along with a house guest who doesn’t play a lot of video games. We were hooked almost from the beginning.

The navigation is simple and reminds me of DVD games. I thought the gameplay would get dull – location, interrogate, repeat, but the pace of clues and strength of the acting kept that from happening. Like most games that rely on questioning suspects, there are questions the player wants to ask that never come up. As this relies on finding contradictions, this does become more of an issue at times, but not to a point that crippled gameplay. There are lots of red herrings or lines of inquiry that go nowhere. I can’t tell you how many times we picked up an item and said “Don’t forget what Simon said about that. That’s important.” only to have nothing happen. Rather than annoy, it left us with a longing for a sequel.

The acting is great. I found Jenks’ shoes and hat a bit annoying, and every time he flourished the evidence at a suspect I expected him to say “Is this your card?”, but it added to his quirkiness. Paul Darrow is great. He brings nuance to the role and is still one of the best “reaction” actors I’ve seen.

The only real downside is replayability. I’d love to get my game night group together to do this, but it won’t be as much fun for me. I’ll still probably do it.

If I were the producers, I’d make a 20 minute playable demo using the existing material and mechanics to help sell this and get money for a sequel on Kickstarter. Something that shows off the ease of interrogation and introduces most of the characters would be a great marketing tool and short enough to share with friends (particularly the non-gamer 40-55 demo who would love this game if they knew it existed).

Superb acting, if a bit goofy at times. Nice high quality video and an entertaining story. My only qualm is with the abrupt, anti-climatic, but still enjoyable ending.\n\nA great throwback to old FMV games, would love to see another.

I enjoyed this game and finished it in a couple of days. It felt like an average quality murder mystery television episode made into a game. reviewText:
To truly appreciate how good this game is, you have to first understand WHAT this game is.  Interactive fiction, yes.  A full-motion video game (FMV), sure.  But more than either of those, it is a modern-day implementation of the age-old tradition of art commission.

A small team of talented and passionate people reached out to the gaming community and humbly petitioned them for support; the help they needed to bring something they truly believed in to life.  In the end, an understandably skeptical KickStarter community offered £4,010.  Let me repeat that.  £4,010.  At that funding level, Contradition is an astonishing achievement; not only in its polish and enjoyability, but also in what had to have been the colossal charity and collaboration of everyone involved in its making.

Contradiction is an interactive fiction experience in the form of a high-definition, full-motion video game.  A young woman has been found dead; drowned in a lake at the outskirts of a charming hamlet in the English country-side.  Detective Jenks arrives on scene at 5:00PM to investigate and finds the inhabitants of the village not nearly as wholesome as their idyllic surroundings.  At the center of it all is an inscrupulous father and son duo and their cut-throat, corporate executive training program, Atlas.  Jenks has until midnight to solve the mystery,  Tour the town, gather the evidence, and interview the witnesses.  Spot the contradictions and help Jenks close the case.  The Chief is counting on you.

This is British Detective Pulp at its finest.  From the quirky and unflappable Detective Jenks to the deliciously villainous patriarch, Paul Rand, great performances throughout elevate the story-telling well past what I would have alllowed a work of this budget and format could deliver.  The settings are lush, but genuine.  The makeup and costumes are just right" in their tasteful understatement.  The music and sound effects create mood and communicate enviroment in as expert a fashion as I have ever heard.

The game design is both intuitive and innovative.  The control interface is clever and unobstrusive; an asset to he gameplay instead of a necessary evil.  The offering of both a hint system and a full-on "cheat" bailout welcomes players of every commitment level.  Chapter progression marked by advancing hours and subsequent nightfall are perfect for communicating urgency in a natural and realistic way.  The game is altogether worthy as a vehicle for delivering the quality acting and engrossing story.

I ran into only two challenges with the gameplay and those are easily overcome with a couple of no-spoiler hints:

1.  Start every new chapter by walking the entire length of the village
recommended: and entering evey location.  The quick-travel map can result in a vital progress point being missed for a frustratingly long time.\n\n2.  The hourglass symbol that signifies that there is something in the scene for Jenks to investigate is easy to miss.  Watch closely for it
hoursPlayed: especially when making the aforementioned new-chapter walkthrough."

I bought this in a bundle and was immediatly interested as I played a lot of these games in the 90's and loved them like Grabriel Knight, Phantasmagoria, Ripper, Tex murphy, The X-files, The Daedalus Encounter, Spycraft, SWAT, Urban Runner or even games like Privateer 2, wing commander 3,4 and probably a few others that I forgot along the way.

If we had that quality of video back them, it would probably have been more wonderfull.
I started it from start to finish over 2 days and realise than I still love this kind of games and would play plenty more of them.

I hope the game get's enough sales and promotion to make more of them, as there are many like me that enjoy these games a lot! I would just suggest one thing is that sometimes you could choose different path so depending the answer you get a slightly different answer, like LA Noire does.

But for the rest good job and great to see some wanting to bring this kind back!

For a game that came from Kickstarer this is a pretty damn good game, harking back to the good old days when people tried to make FMV games the next best thing.

There's some great acting in this, the storyline is fantastic and really pulls you in. The puzzles are pitched at just the right level, not too difficult but hard enough to make you work for it.

There will be a few people that may find the puzzles a little on the difficult side, and will start reaching for a walkthrough, but if you pay attention to what people say, then you'll be able to work most of it out.

I really hope they make a sequel as they've hinted, as this is one game where I really want to see what happens next, I'd loved to have backed this on KS, but at least I've been able to get it on steam and give back to the team that made it.

Great Work

If you like FMVs, murder mysteries, light puzzles and tongue-in-cheek line delivery about  seemingly serious subjects, this is definitely game for you. At first you start serious murder investigation, then you quickly start wondering what on earth is up with this delivery and then you just succumb and wait what wacky stuff is going to happen next.

The world needs more games like this, genuinely brave in times when hype and graphics outweigh entertainment. Cracking storytelling. A no brain purchase, if there is ANYTHING I can do with assisting with a follow-up get in touchI SPREADING THE WORD NOW!!

reviewText: The minute you find the first contradiction, you are hooked. It has a well-written storyline. Loved the balance of red-herrings and important details to keep it just complicated enough to be really fun and engrossing. Can't wait for the next installment.

Excellent game! Very thrilling, great acting, and for the tiny budget that they said was involved, an incredibly fun game. I'd look forward to a sequel, or even better yet, a completely new setting altogether!\n\nHalf of the fun of this game is learning about the culture of the town. What makes the people unique, the interactions between individuals. I love all the mining for brand new information. If there is a sequel, I'd hope that I'd still have that same experience: jumping into a brand new world that I already know nothing about.

Yes I recommend the game but with some caveats. If you enjoy detective shows and/or FMV games you'll love this but despite its very simple interactivity there are some major interface bugs. First of all, never EVER click the middle mouse button or the game will reset on you causing you to lose progress. Secondly, there is no option to skip the video if the interface ever bugs out/becomes unresponsive.  Eventually I learned to get through the game by making sure I left click scrolled for everything.

Once you get past the issues its an incredible game for how little money it was made for, 3000 british pounds. The camera work is top notch and the acting surprisingly watchable which shows the pedigree of the game's maker, a professional DP and British film professional. Leveraging his experience and contacts undoubtedly was the only way the game was made so cheaply. He creates far more of an interesting world and backstory than the game ultimately reveals this time around setting up for a sequel, which hopefully does get made. Ultimately Contradiction is worth supporting so that happens.

8/10 (2 pts off just for the bugginess)

On the whole, spot the liar is exactly what FMV games should be. Tim Follins has figured out a great and simple mechanic to interact with a fairly linear scripted story. Listening to each of the characters detail specific facts only to catch them in a lie is quite rewarding. Although the acting comes across as fairly hammy in the beginning, it grows on you and I'd say works mostly throughout the game.

I played through the entirety of the game with my Girlfriend and we both enjoyed it throughly. The only slight critique I'd have is that the game on occasion requires you to walk around the small village in order to trigger a certain event before letting you continue. There's no real gameplay reason to do this, as the map function conveniently lets you warp most places. In fact, seeing the same travel animations time and time again becomes a little tedious, so it's somewhat counter-intuitive that this is occasionally required for the sake of progression. Perhaps in a future installment the game would force these required encounters if you were to warp past something.

This is - however - a minor detail and on the whole, it was well worth the money spent. Give it a go. It's the type of game that definately deserves a sequel.
Excellent FMV mystery. Highly recommended.

A very well crafted game with a compelling user interface.   They say that this game was created on a tiny budget and it shows but not in any place important.  The actors were very good--they could be (and probably have been) on any quality BBC production.  With a larger budget, they could make the sequel this this truly fantastic.  For example, in this game the characters were always interviewed in the same place.  Ryan seemed to have an endless glass of whiskey over the many hours that the game takes place.  Simon always appears to be in a bright afternoon kitchen even at 11:00 PM.  And Inspector Jenks doesn't have a mobile phone but has to return to a pay phone.

Having the next sequel end with one of the classic mystery wrap ups where you have everyone in the same room and reveal the actual murderer would cost a lot because you would have to record many different video takes that would not be used.  However, the fun there would be you could replay the ending multiple times.

I played this game with my wife and we enjoyed it as much as a good British mystery series--maybe a bit more because it was interactive.  I hope that everyone likes this game as much as I did so that the sequel will be created with a larger budget.

The game definitely has some flaws, mainly with the engine, and the fact that it looks like they have changed the story a few times halfway in the middle before deciding on an ending. The loose ends by the end don't feel like they are planned, and the ending in general did not fulfil the hype.
Having all that said, I most definitely recommend you play this game! It is absolutely delightful! I've always been wondering when someone would bring movie/games back with a proper quality, and this game really makes a good effort. The main character you’d control really overacts his scenes, and it is just hysterical! The puzzles of the game are not hard, but they were never meant to be hard.  It’s all about how much the player pays attention to details. The story is curious and compelling and most of the characters of the story feel right and real.
Overall, I enjoyed the whole experience, and I encourage you to take it on.
Contradiction is a fun and immersive experience for those who enjoy a FMV-style mystery game. The dialog was really well developed, and the acting was enjoyable. Well worth a try.

The game does leave some wants such as maybe a slightly easier way to see the clues you've covered. But all in all I would extremely recommend that if your into story and interesting charecters this is a definite buy.

The goal of the game is to find what happened to Kate (murder or suicide) by investigating a small town and interrogating the people in it. You do that by spotting contradictions (hence the name) in their statements.

I enjoyed the game although i found the ending a bit more abrupt than i expected and a lot of things left unanswered (probably for a possible sequel).

I would reccommend the game to the people that enjoy the genre. There are no illogical puzzles and although the contradiction system is iffy at times (the contradictions are not hard to spot but some times there are contradictions that the game just doesn't care about) the game is still worth it.

As a highlight of the game for me was the main character Inspector Jenks. The actor was really emotive and funny. Cheesy at times but the good kind.

I bought this game solely because Paul Darrow is in it. I wasn’t expecting much from the game. To my delight, Contradiction – Spot the Liar made for an entertaining evening… and late evening… then early morning…  I hooked my pc to the big screen and played along with a house guest who doesn’t play a lot of video games. We were hooked almost from the beginning.

The navigation is simple and reminds me of DVD games. I thought the gameplay would get dull – location, interrogate, repeat, but the pace of clues and strength of the acting kept that from happening. Like most games that rely on questioning suspects, there are questions the player wants to ask that never come up. As this relies on finding contradictions, this does become more of an issue at times, but not to a point that crippled gameplay. There are lots of red herrings or lines of inquiry that go nowhere. I can’t tell you how many times we picked up an item and said “Don’t forget what Simon said about that. That’s important.” only to have nothing happen. Rather than annoy, it left us with a longing for a sequel.

The acting is great. I found Jenks’ shoes and hat a bit annoying, and every time he flourished the evidence at a suspect I expected him to say “Is this your card?”, but it added to his quirkiness. Paul Darrow is great. He brings nuance to the role and is still one of the best “reaction” actors I’ve seen.

The only real downside is replayability. I’d love to get my game night group together to do this, but it won’t be as much fun for me. I’ll still probably do it.

If I were the producers, I’d make a 20 minute playable demo using the existing material and mechanics to help sell this and get money for a sequel on Kickstarter. Something that shows off the ease of interrogation and introduces most of the characters would be a great marketing tool and short enough to share with friends (particularly the non-gamer 40-55 demo who would love this game if they knew it existed).
I really enjoyed playing this game with my son.

I bought this in a bundle and was immediatly interested as I played a lot of these games in the 90's and loved them like Grabriel Knight, Phantasmagoria, Ripper, Tex murphy, The X-files, The Daedalus Encounter, Spycraft, SWAT, Urban Runner or even games like Privateer 2, wing commander 3,4 and probably a few others that I forgot along the way.

If we had that quality of video back them, it would probably have been more wonderfull.
I started it from start to finish over 2 days and realise than I still love this kind of games and would play plenty more of them.

I hope the game get's enough sales and promotion to make more of them, as there are many like me that enjoy these games a lot! I would just suggest one thing is that sometimes you could choose different path so depending the answer you get a slightly different answer, like LA Noire does.

But for the rest good job and great to see some wanting to bring this kind back!

I really cannot wait for the sequel if they decide to make it!

This game plays like a watered down Phoenix Wright mixed with elements of Her Story, the gameplay involves you interviewing various suspects in a small village and finding contradictions in what they say, as well as being provided with new information or evidence once you find these.

Despite not being an action intensive game, whereby you mostly watch videos of interviews, I found it almost impossible to put this game down and I completed it in one sitting due to the story grasping me, and despite getting through it quite quickly it still took me over 5 hours to reach the end.

The brilliant acting paired with the story progression makes this FMV detective game one of the best hidden gems that I have played in a long time. Additionally during the credits I found out it is filmed in my local area, so I'll be sure to have a scout round for the locations!

I would rate this higher than Her Story as it has loveable characters (most of them), a clear, definitive ending which also hints at a sequel and the constant twisting and turning of the story leaving it impossible for you to guess early on and get bored.

5/5 - definitely worth the full price, and you have to get this if you see it any cheaper.

Superb acting, if a bit goofy at times. Nice high quality video and an entertaining story. My only qualm is with the abrupt, anti-climatic, but still enjoyable ending.\n\nA great throwback to old FMV games, would love to see another.

For a game that came from Kickstarer this is a pretty damn good game, harking back to the good old days when people tried to make FMV games the next best thing.

There's some great acting in this, the storyline is fantastic and really pulls you in. The puzzles are pitched at just the right level, not too difficult but hard enough to make you work for it.

There will be a few people that may find the puzzles a little on the difficult side, and will start reaching for a walkthrough, but if you pay attention to what people say, then you'll be able to work most of it out.

I really hope they make a sequel as they've hinted, as this is one game where I really want to see what happens next, I'd loved to have backed this on KS, but at least I've been able to get it on steam and give back to the team that made it.

It seemed like a lot of the mystery we uncovered ended up being inconsequential and too quickly disgarded in the end. No matter, because while the destination may have been drab the ride was a blast. Fun FMV game!

The plot was intriguing and at times... creepy. So creepy. The solutions weren't always obvious, I had to really dig through the statements to find the contradictions. So while it's still possible to solve the case without using any hints, don't expect it to be a cakewalk.
The performances were great, there was a good balance between 'comical' and 'chillingly intense'. Spotting the lies and then making Jenks grill the suspects was very enjoyable: go Jenks!
The cinematography was beautiful and there were subtle dolly-ins/zoom-ins at just the right moments. The brilliant application of dissolve - together with the UI and controls - made the experience seamless, simple and stunning. Sound design was equally detailed and amazing.
The game guides the player to the solution and it's impossible to improvise, but I don't see this as a bad thing. It's like an interactive mystery novel: while you can have your suspicions, the story still only has one ending and you're just along for the ride. I enjoyed this ride immensely and can't wait for more!

We really enjoyed Contradiction. It was a lot of fun to play as a team, sharing ideas as we made our way through it. This game was _amazing_. Highly reccommended! Not just a fun game but a legitimately gripping story all the way through!

This was a charming detective game that left me feeling very satisfied by its conclusion. As other reviewers have noted, the acting is weird, stilted, and melodramatic. Somewhere between a latin soap opera and David Lynch project, set in a rural English town. And the UI is servicable, but not pretty or easy-to-use.

But the actual act of bumbling through interviews to solve the mystery is exciting in its execution. The game asks you to build a detailed mental model of what's really going on in the town, and rewards you for making remote connections.

And one of the more interesting ways it does this is by not letting you gotcha" a suspect by surprising them with information given by another interviewee. Every character provides plausible responses to each new piece of evidence presented
date: but is only pressured into breaking character when you actually find contradictions in what they have said themselves.\n\nFor example

Interactive detective movie in a small village. This game was like a breath of fresh air - good concept - very well implemented with good script and slick editing for modest cast - quite fun - best tried with friends or family together with output to TV screen - occasional rare minor interface bugs but easily overcome - some scenes and acting quirky and quaint but all the funnier for that - there is enough for a couple of evenings or one very long one - would fit in with a weekend effort with friends or family nicely.

Was very happy to forgive any minor shortcomings of this game because overall the effort and polish of what was attempted was accomplished very impressively; it is not easy to script, edit, act out and film such a work so well - the developers have done a good job on this - appreciate it and I hope you will enjoy this interactive TV detective show as much as we did.

I picked it up when on a heavily discounted price tag and found it great value entertainment - I don't often review games but this delivered what I was expecting and was fun - deserves support, success and sequels.

Contradiction is a fantastic game. It is essentially a throwback to classic FMV games from back in the day. It doesn‘t take itself too seriously but still does have it‘s serious moments. The gameplay is barely existent but that is kind of the point. The gameplay really focuses on the player finding contradictions in people‘s statements and reactions to items you show them and tales that you tell them. My favorite character has to be the main character: Detective Inspector Frederick Jenks, played expertly by Rupert Booth. He does a fantastic job at being serious in most moments but does have his silly moments as well. An honorable mention here would be Paul Darrow as the Atlus money man, Paul Rand. He does a really good job in his role. I won‘t spoil the ending here but, suffice to say, it did surprise me and took me a while to figure it out. All in all I love Contradiction and I really hope that a sequel does happen.

After watching some eps from Jesse and Dodger's playthrough of it I had to go out and get this for myself and it was probably the most fun I've had with a mystery game like this. Most mystery adventure games I've played are pretty serious, gets you into the mood because it's crime game. Contradiction, while it didn't get me into a serious mood, it did get me into a mood that made me really care about Jenks, very invested into Atlus, and wanting to close this case. Also, the actors... Though the acting is kind of weak at some points it really added to their personality and how you feel about them and this game (Jenks, Paul, Rebecca, and James being my faves). I had so much fun playing this game and I really do hope they end up making a sequel because I really want to know more about Atlus OR have Jenks in more games. He can really be the Sherlock or Nancy of FMVs.\n\nNow... All that being said, I do feel that the ending came about a little too... simple. You closed the case you came here for, but now you're left with so may questions that can be brought up in later installments; I get it. But the way it ended just felt weak like it was all building up to something only to come to that. I understand what they did and if they're trying to get you more interested in all this weird ♥♥♥ Atlus ♥♥♥♥ by leaving off with an ending like that, then GOD DAMN it worked on me!

I hope a sequal comes out. 10/10 I think everyone should play this game.

This game is a cosy investigation played out in gorgeous FMV segments. We sat down to try it out and ended up spending 6 hours playing the entire thing in one sitting. The story and characters draw you in almost immediately and you can't help but keep playing as contradictions and evidence gradually get unearthed.

As far as the story goes, it's an engaging murder mystery set in an English village full of quirky characters. It's a very visually satisfying and well made game. The live action video format is really well used here - it doesn't feel at odds with the gameplay at all and most of the scenes are beautifully shot. The whole thing has a great cast - Jenks, Rebecca, Paul and Ryan are particularly well done. The feel is campy whodunit fun with some sinister undertones and the game balances it very well. It's challenging enough to make you feel like you're putting the detective work in, without being frustratingly impossible. The answers are all there if you look for them and you get a huge feeling of satisfaction every time you catch someone out in a lie.

Fantastic and novel game - fingers crossed for a sequel.

reviewText:
Beautiful murder mystery adventure game. A lot of amazing comedy in the line deliveries, great acting performances.

Game itself has maybe a bit too much back and forth like you have to go back to each character you're interviewing a lot for every new piece of dialogue or clue you can ask them about, not really sure how that could be made different though. There maybe aren't enough item or environment puzzles, only very few inventory items you use in the world, and it's all very basic. The inventory is mostly for storing different topics to move all the different characters' dialogues.

Quite a few smaller plot threads don't necessarily lead anywhere except in a roundabout way to other clues on semi-related topics you use with different characters than the plot thread originally were about, not really red herrings just stuff that doesn't feel sufficiently followed up on. So there could possibly have been added quite a bit more smaller dialogues for that stuff. And the last few chapters feel a bit short or rushed maybe, the ending is definitely weird and hinges on a pretty random item and a cutscene that kind of forces the ending to happen without a lot of player interaction.

Really like how you get bits and pieces of information from the different characters, but you can't just go around accusing people, you have to catch them all in contradictions of their own. Can only use things said against the person that said it, not what someone else said. So you're always sitting with a bit of a bigger picture informationwise, just drawing your own conclusions from what several people are saying, than you're getting from each character on their own. Really nicely written.

Overall a really fun story with great characters.
Really liked it!

_\m/ <o> <o> <o> _\m/\n\nA nice quirky campy adventure game. That got surprisingly dark in tone.  Great effort for a first game by the sole developer. Does have a few of the traditional adventure game tropes where you tend to get stuck and can't see a way forward other than what the game wants you to do.

I can easily say this is the most immersive, rewarding, and satisfying game I've played in recent memory. This is what the FMV games of old always aspired to be but could never actually quite achieve.

Contradiction is a fittingly theatrical experience that plays just like an interactive movie. You play as Inspector Jenks, who is merely a polite and humble police officer going about his job. Little else is shown about Jenks, except for occasionally emphasized spades of moral fortitude and righteous indignation, and helpful hints and speculations in the form of brief inner monologues. His more hollowed out vagueness serves as an appropriate vessel for the player to experience the story in, where the progress of the plot hinges on their every move, while managing to avoid coming off cliche or one-dimensional.

Jenks is investigating the death of a young woman named Kate Vine who was found in a lake in the woods, and has less than an entire day to solve the mystery (fortunately, the game does not progress in real time or possess a time limit, or else this would be much more difficult). His suspects and witnesses include a well-rounded cast of characters each with their own quirks and individuality, each of whom are equally amusing and interesting.

Contradiction is a thoroughly cerebral experience, as it requires you to constantly remain engaged in every detail you come across, similar to how classic Sierra Adventure games encourage players to explore every proverbial nook and cranny. The game doesn't hold your hand when you feel sure enough to try to figure things out on your own, but will give you just enough information to get back on track when you're stuck. You progress by investigating numerous places and seeking out evidence, as well as interviewing suspects and witnesses and checking the evidence against them, as well as their responses to that evidence, and whether or not their stories add up.

Using only filmed footage and photographs in place of computer generated graphics, it works remarkably well with presenting a gorgeous environment and sets, along with aesthetically pleasant costume designs. Even more impressively so given that it was all shot on a low budget, funnily enough reminiscent of the kind of thing you might see on BBC.

The acting may not exactly be Oscar worthy, but is still quite well done. Overall, the game's cinematic presence is easy to appreciate. With just the right balance between a plucky Sherlock mystery and a seedy film noir, it establishes a darkly playful tone, feeling right at home with themes such as the occult and Satanic forces, along with a balanced critique of Objectivism not unlike the first BioShock (major plot points even revolve around an institution called Atlas being run by a father and son team named the Rands; at one point, the phrase greed is good" is quoted).

For $9.99

reviewText:
Excellent murder mystery game, which would be amazing even without the FMV. The contradiction system works superbly 90% of the time, the characters are deep and varied, and new locations open up all the time.

Some will say that the game doesn't hand out enough clues. I'll say this is patently false. On top of the hint system, players can call the Chief, and even get flat-out cheats to help them along when needed. The ever-increasing amount of conversation points also means that the amount of answers to verify grows as well -- but that just means you can't be expected to simply throw statements at one another hoping they will stick. One has to fully remember everything to get around in Contradiction.

The most disheartening thing I have seen regarding this game is the Rock Paper Shotgun review for it. By saying the game should directly tell the players when new events are available at locations, when contradictions are left to be made -- and with whom -- the author only put his inability to appreciate freedom on display. TellTale's The Walking Dead this is not. This is very much a game, and not an interactive story. The only valid point that review brought forth is the game's technical shortcomings; it is true that the lack of resolution options is jarring, and the general UI and presentation is odd at first. But not only is it absolutely not a deal breaker, I feel like it kind of gave the game a very distinct, simple vibe. It was never distracting or frustrating. It took me a couple of minutes to get used to it, then I never gave it a thought again.

Really, for all fans of classic, hardcore adventure games, looking for a modern take (in terms of presentation) on the classic genre, Contradiction is a gift from the Gods. Do not hesitate. Do not watch trailers. Do not try to know anything about it, except that it is a great, great game. Just dive in, headfirst. You'll thank me!
Highly recommended for murder mystery fans!

reviewText: This game is seriously awesome!! Really a must play.

Highly recommend! If you like Deadly Premonition, Twin Peaks, as well as goofy ♥♥♥ B-movies. This one is all about interesting characters and interacting with them to try and solve a murder. The gameplay consists of watching the main character interview the people in town and then you as the player find contradictions within their stories. A bit on the clunky side but has been patched. If you get passed the repetition of going back and forth on the map you will be very pleased with one of the most memorable games in years!

The plot was intriguing and at times... creepy. So creepy. The solutions weren't always obvious, I had to really dig through the statements to find the contradictions. So while it's still possible to solve the case without using any hints, don't expect it to be a cakewalk.
The performances were great, there was a good balance between 'comical' and 'chillingly intense'. Spotting the lies and then making Jenks grill the suspects was very enjoyable: go Jenks!
The cinematography was beautiful and there were subtle dolly-ins/zoom-ins at just the right moments. The brilliant application of dissolve - together with the UI and controls - made the experience seamless, simple and stunning. Sound design was equally detailed and amazing.
The game guides the player to the solution and it's impossible to improvise, but I don't see this as a bad thing. It's like an interactive mystery novel: while you can have your suspicions, the story still only has one ending and you're just along for the ride. I enjoyed this ride immensely and can't wait for more!

Some of the clues were a little frustrating, but the final one was so very satisfying. reviewText:
Do you enjoy mystery games and might be interested in trying out full-motion video (FMV) games then look no further!

Contradiction is a simple point and click game. You travel back and fourth between various suspects to question about clues that you find or through talking to other suspects. The main aspect that sets Contradiction apart are the full-motion video that feature great actors; my favorites being Jenks and Paul. It does remind me of a beloved series Ace Attorney although it is much more simplified but still enjoyable.

As the entire game is shot in full-motion video, it is a joy to watch and interact with the game. You can really tell when a character is nervous or lying from their acting. The most endearing part is the investigator, Jenks with his comical expressions.

Although this game is quite straightforward and not really a game that you need to replay I think it is still worth playing. I do agree with some that the ending is bittersweet as you slowly uncover deep hidden evils within the settings and characetrs, however I think it is only an encouragement for a sequel that I really hope they will go ahead with. If they end up promoting their sequel onto KickStarter, I know I would love to help fund it.
decent fmv love these games feel verey nostalgic 6/10 hoping for a sequel

I really enjoyed this game.  The interaction with all the various characters and the clues made it very interesting.  My husband and I played the game together so we would bandy ideas back and forth, often times reacting to the contradictions we heard in an interview at the same moment.\n\nWe both really loved the setting being in England, and the quality of the video was very good.  I love good crime dramas so this game fit very well into my wheel house.  There was one point where we hit a snag and didn't know how to proceed, but we took a bit of a pause on the game and came back with fresh ideas the next day.  There was something about this game that just made us want to play.  We both would be thinking about the case" all day while at work and as soon as we could we would come back to playing to see what else we could find.  Both my husband and I would highly recommend this game to anyone."

Contradiction is a fantastic game. It is essentially a throwback to classic FMV games from back in the day. It doesn‘t take itself too seriously but still does have it‘s serious moments. The gameplay is barely existent but that is kind of the point. The gameplay really focuses on the player finding contradictions in people‘s statements and reactions to items you show them and tales that you tell them. My favorite character has to be the main character: Detective Inspector Frederick Jenks, played expertly by Rupert Booth. He does a fantastic job at being serious in most moments but does have his silly moments as well. An honorable mention here would be Paul Darrow as the Atlus money man, Paul Rand. He does a really good job in his role. I won‘t spoil the ending here but, suffice to say, it did surprise me and took me a while to figure it out. All in all I love Contradiction and I really hope that a sequel does happen.

reviewText: Contradiction isn't exactly the best game in my library and it was rather simplistic and quick to plow through. The characters seemed a little flat in all honesty without much in the way of depth to figuring them out and it seemed that this was one of those I need to rush through cases that really didn't need to be rushed and it's rather linear with things being hard to miss and there's not much of a replay value unless you want to work through a speed record.\n\nNow this isn't to say it is a terrible game. The simplicity of it shows care given to the indie style that it is. They went basic and put more effort into the concept of finding the mystery then sending you out and about which shows that while they want to make an awesome game that will last they want you to ENJOY the game which is more than what a lot of indie makers these days seem to do.

I really enjoyed the core mechanic of this game, which is given away in the title. The scenes and acting were delightful, and I especially liked stumbling across scenes that weren't expected. I'd love to see a sequel!\n\nCritcisms- only that I want to be even more involved in the story than our investigator was! This game definitely walked the tightrope of being too close to simply watching a movie. While I'd say the creators succeeded in avoiding that, I'd like to see the game depart even further from it. I realize that may be pretty difficult, given the nature of the game. There was a lot to keep track of and to keep consistent, and I imagine that's a difficult balance. Bottom line, I'd recommend it.

This was a great mystery game. It's unique, interesting, and most of all, fun to play. The game comes with a built-in hint and cheat system that is very forgiving; this is in fact one of my two complaints. It feels like mystery games shouldn't be this easy; you get directions and suggestions on where to go anytime for no penalty. My other complaint is that there are parts where it can drag on a bit, but otherwise, it's good.

I definitely recommend this game if you're looking for a new mystery game to play.

Also, I definitely want a sequel to this sometime.

I will say...okay, I have three complaints. There were times where it took me an unnecessary amount of time to find a contradiction. Some are hard to spot, which is good, but each conversation gives you only tidbits of what was said, and the vague descriptions + vague connections can make figuring it out hard. And you can't contradict between witnesses, you can only find contradictions within the person's own testimony.
